subject: Art & Design
title: Color Grading: How Color Sets the Mood
description: A quick win: understand Color Grading: How Color Sets the Mood.

hook.text: The Matrix is green-tinted inside the simulation. The real world is cold blue. Color tells you where you are.

buildup.text: Color grading is the process of adjusting colors in post-production to create a specific visual mood.

discovery.text: Warm tones (orange, yellow) suggest nostalgia, comfort. Cool tones (blue, teal) suggest isolation, tension.

twist.text: Hollywood's most common grade: teal and orange. It makes skin tones pop against cool backgrounds.

climax.text: Wes Anderson uses candy colors for whimsy. David Fincher uses desaturated palettes for grit. Style is color.

punchline.text: A film's color palette is its emotional fingerprint.

quiz.question: Why does Hollywood frequently use the teal-and-orange color grade?
options: It makes warm skin tones pop against cool backgrounds
Those colors are cheapest to produce digitally
Audiences subconsciously prefer those two colors
